messages.message: Here's an example of the model coming back with 3 different answers for the same question :disappointed: cc: @Hari @Sławek Biel

docs attached
and this Wiki imported via URL - Arsenal F.C. - Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arsenal_F.C.)

<!subteam^S06395ZEFSL> can you do some debugging why the model struggles here?

@avi is one of the answers here the expected one?
Yeah, the middle one - `Kai Havertz` . Though football fans will understand why a model finds it tough to believe :see_no_evil:
@Subash @Aayush @vineeth Can we get the new MS-Lite into multidocs, chatbots as well? This is anyway internal so we can keep testing the determinism of this model!
~I think it's pulling `Pierre-Emerick` from the wikipedia article~  Actually you're right, it's not in the article
You can try the chatbot here actually, made it as a public unlisted chatbot - https://aihub.instabase.com/hub/apps/shared/avi.vaid/Arsenal%2023-24%20Season

Ok. There seems to be 2 issues:

1. Model is using it's own knowledge to answer question: 
    a. Highest paid player is Pierre_Emerick
    b. Kal Havertz is not an Arsenal Player
2. The user's question is `who is our highest paid player` and when search tool executes, it gets converted into `Who is the highest paid player at Arsenal?`. This might be because the question uses the word `our` and based on the documents, the model assumes it is about Arsenal.
Why do you say Kai Havertz isn't an Arsenal player? IRL he is, but also in the docs it's never indicated he isn't

The model is saying that. If you look at the Progress tool output, it mentions the reason why it ignored Kai Havertz and it says he is not an Arsenal player. Did he recently join Arsenal? Knowledge cut off for gpt-4-1106-preview is April 2023.
Ohh interesting, yeah he joined `28 June 2023`, I forgot about model training cutoff

It’s kind of tricky here, the player_salaries file does not mention the club. The model would need to crossreference with the wikipedia article, but it doesn’t do it.
@avi Can you check if renaming ‘player_salaries’ to ‘arsenal_player_salaries’ helps?
Yeah totally get how this can become tricky :disappointed: I'll test that change!
@jayasooryan the model knowledge leak happens in the SearchTool here, maybe we can add a sentence there to only use the document contents?
Would there be scenarios where we actually need model's knowledge to answer a question?
Yeah good point, if I ask about French people and the document mentions someone born in Paris we’d like the model to be able to do that connection
it seems the doc rename really helps!
I wonder if we should add context to the docs automatically baed on our understanding of the knowledge base too
As we scale to many data sources, it's likely docs will be named quite vaguely :disappointed:
A chat bot level system prompt would be another way. If the model knew all the documents relate to Arsenal that would be good enough

Yeah, this can open many more possibilities too. Getting answers in a specific style, coaching the model on creativity level, and eventually maybe even function calling - [EPD-1285] Custom instructions/Pre-Processing/Post-Processing for Chatbot queries - Jira (atlassian.net) (https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/EPD-1285)
But the doc description may help for non-chatbot scenarios in search/converse
We generate descriptions for each doc independently. I don’t have a good idea how to achieve the “understanding of the knowledge base” bit.
